subject: RE: [junit] parallel test directories and eclipse
msgSnippet: ... I don t use VSS so I don t know what files you mean, but I do wonder why their part of the project. ... My philosophy is that, when adopting a new
messageBody:
Stevens, Timothy J. asked:
> This is somewhat off topic, but when I tried doing this
> I got errors from Eclipse about duplicate files. The problem
> is my Visual Source Safe files that are left in every
> directory, and always named the same. Is it possible to to
> get Eclipse to ignore duplicate files?

I don't use VSS so I don't know what files you mean, but I do wonder why
their part of the project.

> Also, when you specify multiple input directories like
> this, doesn't bunch all of your class files from the various
> directory structures together? I tend to like to keep my
> class files in the same directories as their respective java
> files, but that's just me...

My philosophy is that, when adopting a new language, you should adopt the
common conventions with that language. When I did C and assembler, I kept
the object files in the same directory as the source. With java, that's not
the normal convention. I quickly found that many tools, including some of
Sun's, did not handle things gracefully with that convention once the source
occupied more than one directory. Therefore I always set an output
directory for the class files.

I realize that neither of these answers help you do what you're trying to
do. They only raise questions about what your trying to do. I'm sorry I
don't have any better help.

- George
